node.text:
⠀
☑︎ follow @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
⠀
————
So many of you are reaching out that your little one cannot sustain attention on one activity for long and that is totally OK ! Actually, the attention span of a child about is about 2 to 3 minutes per year, so
- a 2 yr’s engagement can be expected to 📉wind down after about ⏱5 min🤩
- 4 yr after about 10 min, etc.
⠀
HOW TO PROLONG IT❓
INCORPORATE 🏃🏽 MOVEMENT‼️
⠀
Recent research actually suggests that children are learning MORE while actively moving rather than when passively sitting 🪑 and thus MOVEMENT is indispensable for a healthy development of a young child as whole: physically, cognitively, and emotionally! So let’s get moving!!
⠀
🚨Have you joined Montessori MADE EASY Membership 👉🏻
⠀
https://montessorifromtheheart.com/product/homeschool-montessori-made-easy-membership/
⠀

node.text:
#Montessori Practical Life
⠀
☑︎ follow @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
————
Details on my 📃blog
⠀
 https://montessorifromtheheart.com/2016/10/11/the-cycle-of-an-apple-and-apple-serving-activity/
⠀
•••••••••
Dr. Maria Montessori through her scientific observation came to a conclusion that children are naturally curious and seek to participate in daily life activities they see all around them. They innately want to feel useful, helpful and contributing members of the family. “Help me do it myself!” Proclaims a child bursting with confidence and enthusiasm!  And so she developed practical life exercises to give children an opportunity to develop and master important practical life skills, gain independence and become fully functional members of the family and community.
⠀
💡 You can start as early as 15 M with simple activities such as cleaning fruits or veggies or loading laundry. Trust me, your little one is capable of great skills if given an opportunity to DO THE DOING!
⠀
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕
⠀
••••••••••••••••
Have you joined Montessori MADE EASY Membership❓Details 👉🏻
⠀
https://montessorifromtheheart.com/product/homeschool-montessori-made-easy-membership/
⠀

node.text:
☑︎ follow @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
————
Dr. Maria Montessori observed that children are naturally curious and seek to participate in daily life activities they see all around them. So she developed practical life exercises to give children an opportunity to practice important skills, gain independence and become fully functional members of the family and community.
⠀
💡 Did you know you can offer a small palm brush to a 15 M old and invite to clean fruits or vegetables? Trust me, your little one is capable of great skills if given an opportunity to DO THE DOING!
⠀
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
⚖️ 🔵🟡🟣🔴🟢GROSS MOTOR FUN
⠀
☑︎ follow @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
————
So many of you are reaching out that your little one cannot sustain attention on one activity for long and that is totally OK ! Actually, the attention span of a child about is about 2 to 3 minutes per year and did you know that most children need movement!!! Recent research actually suggests that children are learning more while actively moving rather than when passively sitting 🪑 And PE (physical exercise) breaks are absolutely indispensable for a healthy development of a child as whole: physically, cognitively, and emotionally! So let’s get moving!!
⠀
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
⠀
☑︎ follow @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
————
So many of you have requested, so I am sharing our learning space, as well as how I store and organize materials.
⠀
Please note, you do NOT need a big room or a lot of materials to embrace Montessori! (What you see, is the accumulation of nearly 10 years!) I started with a small corner shelf in an apartment’s enclosed balcony! And it was ENOUGH to bring the joy of learning and make our homeschooling center on the CHILD! It’s not about the size or quantity of things you have, it’s about the METHOD and YOUR desire to make it happen! Do NOT let anything stop 🛑 you! And I am here to help if you have any questions ❓
⠀
••••••••••••••••

node.text:
EARTHWORM 📦 DIY
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
Parts of 🪱by 👦🏼Adrian ♡
Lifecycle by 👧🏻Julia ♡
________
Finishing up Earthworm 🪱 study with this parts of and lifecycle #DIY!
⠀
🚨Montessori Made-Easy Members make sure to 📥download all the 🪱Earthworm study PDFs as we will be studying 🐝 🦋 INSECTs next 🥰
••••
“Education is a natural process carried out by the child and is not acquired by listening to words but by experiences in the environment.” Dr. Maria Montessori
⠀
I used to 😱scream when I saw 🪱one! But after learning so much about these indispensable nightcrawlers who are so essential to our ecosystem I came to respect them! And my kids are totally over them! “Earthworms have 5 ❤️hearts !! How not to like them!” says Adrian 😜
⠀
YOU’ll NEED:
- ♻️recycled 📦cardboard (I am using pizza 🍕 insert)
- markers @artezaofficial
- black beans to resemble soil
- earthworm 🪱 life cycle by @safariltd
——
AGE 4 yr +⚠️Always supervise your child!
••••••••••••••
💡 WHY HANDS-ON LEARNING?
⠀
It allows little people to engage in kinesthetic learning by doing! 🙌🏻’Hands-on learning’ is the common name for ‘Experiential Learning’ - the philosophical term behind the method of immersing oneself in a process in order to learn it. Experiential Learning has been around since 350 BCE, when Aristotle wrote, "for the things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them". Most importantly, hands-on learning is uniquely positioned to support or elevate ANY type of learner! Best of all, research has proven that children who learn using hands-on methods with manipulatives, outperform those who are not. What are manipulatives? They are physical tools engaging children visually and physically with objects suc
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕
⠀

node.text:
🐚 COUNTING 🔢
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
——
These 🪣 pages are part of 🐚 ⛵️ Seaside SUMMER ACTIVITY Pack - enter promo SUMMER50 for 50%OFF this 77 page printable pack. FREE larger 🪣🖨available from my store!
⠀
Math and science require a certain analytical skill. Some children have it intuitively via 🧬 genetic  aptitudes and other don’t. And recent research indicates that the longer it takes to assimilate the subject , the deeper the understanding is. So whether your little one💡 gets it right away or needs time to process, I suggest making math activities hands-on and engaging to kindle the interest!
⠀
You’ll NEED:
- recycled 📦 cardboard
- 🐚 🖨 printout
⠀
HOW TO: 👁 See my stories 👆🏻
⠀
AGE: 2.5 yo+ ⚠️Always supervise your child!
———
💡 Rote Counting vs. Rational Counting:
The difference between rote and rational counting is that the first is a process of sequentially memorizing number names and the second is the process of understanding the value of numbers. If a child is only able to recite numbers in order, just like a heart-learned-poem, it by no means indicates the actual mathematical understanding of numbers.  Trust me, 1:1 correspondence is a much better indication of your child’s mathematical mastery than a long list of memorized numbers. And the best part, you can introduce 1:1 correspondence starting at an early age by modeling through real-life manipulative and hands-on DIYs.
⠀
Also, a Ten- Frame is a visual tool to help children ‘see’ numbers concretely, understand place value and learn essential strategies needed for future mental addition and subtraction. For preschoolers, a single 10 frame is extremely helpful to visualize fact families.
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
🍊 CITRUS SQUEEZING ACTIVITY
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
———
“Montessori Practical Life is more than the wonderful feeling of doing real work, of being helpful to others! This work also sharpens valuable mental skills including planning, organization, task initiation, working memory, self-regulation, flexibility, goal-directed persistence, and sustained attention. These are executive functions of the brain, and are more reliable predictors of academic achievements than even IQ scores.”
⠀
•••••••
You can start involving your little one in real practical life activities as early as 15 months! Start with simple fruits or veggie washing (use a palm brush with stiff bristles). Offer them to load laundry 🧺or peel a banana 🍌 for a snack!
⠀
Try it! You will be amazed how much little people are capable of! They want to feel important, independent and useful! What for us is a dreadful chore, for them is a desired task!
⠀
Tag me 🔖
⠀
All the details are on the Montessori Made Easy portal ~ under Practical Life activities! Join now!
⠀
⠀
 𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
Elephant 🐘 Toothpaste 🧪
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
———
This 🌈 #stem experiment 🧫 has been on our list to do for a long while! However, all the explosions you see on YouTube are using peroxide strength I could not get my hands on 😤Well! Kids had a blast and it was SAFE to conduct 🧪 at home!
⠀
YOU’LL NEED:
- hydrogen peroxide (the more concentrated it is, the more the explosion you’ll get!)
- dish soap
- food coloring
- yeast (diluted in warm water)
⠀
——
AGE 5 - 100 Y+ ⚠️Always supervise your child!
⠀

node.text:
🍦ICE CREAM SCOOPs MATCHING
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
________
Is it hot 🥵 where you are? I literally want to take my skin off 😝Tell me ways you cool down?
⠀
We are definitely screaming for ice cream!!! For fun fun math inspired DIY
⠀
YOU’ll NEED:
- recycled cardboard 📦
- ♻️milk or water caps
- a glue gun
- markers to draw a cone 🍦
- dot stickers
- pom poms
- tongs for transferring pom poms (optional)
⠀
SKILLs:
-🖐🏻 hand 👁 eye coordination
- 👌🏻fine motor control
- color matching
- numeracy skills
⠀
Here are 3 variations you can use this DIY:
⠀
- [18 M+] color match and fine motor
- [4Y +] Friends of 🔟 (4💖+ 6💙)
- [5 Y+] Addends of 10 (4❤️+3💚+2🧡+1💜)
⠀
——
⚠️Always supervise your child!
⠀
••••••••••••
🚨Have you joined my Homeschool Montessori MADE EASY Membership❓I constantly add new themed unit study! Check out fun math-inspired 🍦ice cream printable under Main Portal.
⠀
Details to join 👉🏻
⠀
https://montessorifromtheheart.com/product/homeschool-montessori-made-easy-membership/
⠀
•••••••••
💡 Hands-on learning is a form of education where children are learning by doing. So, instead of merely listening, little people are making, creating, and actively engaging. As such, they experience a huge 🧠 increase in the amount of information that they retain.
⠀
Offering children to VISUALLY reconstruct a pattern requires a lot of skills!  For example, learning  matching skills early on will support children to match letters and sounds in Reception class. Also matching skills are triggered  during visual discrimination. And little people use matching skills to tell whether two words or letters are the same or different.
⠀
So offer FUN engaging DIYs to develop MATCHING SKILL!
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
🌈DYED 🍚RICE 🔎SEEK & FIND
@MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
______________
 Now you know what to do with that dyed rice 😆We have done this activity with alphabet, and now it’s numeracy turn!
⠀
🌈Dyed rice 🍚 has been our absolute ❤️ favorite sensory ✍🏻tracing filler!
⠀
WHY?
- it FEELS amazing (for any child with tactile sensitivity this is an amazing filler as it’s not sticky/slimy/ mushy ... so a perfect starter)

- 🗓 lasts FOREVER
- it’s PERFECT for hiding numbers, letters m, puzzle 🧩 pieces, etc.
⠀
📥 Get DYED RICE recipe 🖨PDF 👆🏻link in bio 🌈🍚RECIPE 📝
⠀
http://eepurl.com/gFxjlj
⠀
•••••••••
💡 Sensory play offers MANY benefits! Besides offering various textures to explore the senses, it also promotes fine motor control, hand eye coordination and sparks creative play! In addition, sensory invitations to play promote language development as you describe the texture/ filler using adjectives or point out the spatial relationship between objects using preposition (in/under/next to).
⠀
Sensory play also stimulates 🧠 brain growth and cognitive development by building nerve connections within the developing brain's neural pathways, which triggers a child's inclination for and ability in competing more complex learning tasks.
⠀
————

node.text:
☀️ SHADOW ✏️TRACING
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
________
Shadow tracing has been our absolute favorite ever since Adrian was 3 YO. There is SO much to learn! From where does the ☀️ sun rises and sets, to when can you get the longest shadow (hint: about 4-5 pm)
⠀
Have you tried shadow tracings ❓
⠀
••••••
A lot of you are reaching out to me in🤯agony that your little one does not have a sustained attention for long! That is totally 👌🏻 OK! Although a normal attention span is 2-3 ⏱minutes per year of a child's age, so ave is about👇🏻:
⠀
• 2 years old: four to six minutes
• 4 years old: eight to 12 minutes
• 6 years old: 12 to 18 minutes
⠀
⚠️TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN❓
⠀
1️⃣Bring CREATIVITY to projects (It is much more fun to trace ☀️shadow of 🦓zebra then tracing ABC in the workbook😤)
2️⃣KNOW YOUR CHILD’s INTERESTs 🚘 🧚‍♀️ 🦖 🚜 🐶 🦄
3️⃣VARY & keep it SIMPLE!
⠀
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
🌊PLAY FOAM #SMALLWORLD
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
————
Have you joined  Montessori MADE-EASY❓OCEAN theme is next 😉
⠀
Ok! It’s officially 90+ 🥵and water play is my absolute favorite sensory medium (⚠️though be mindful children can drown in less than 2 inches of water) And if you add food coloring, you can have a FUN #invitationtoplay which is a perfect messy not so messy alternative if your little one does not like anything slimy or sticky! 🥴
⠀
HOW:
- 1/2 of cup of 💦water
- mix 1/4 c of baby- safe tear 😢 free liquid soap or body wash
- add 1 drop of 💙food coloring (too much will stain 🙌🏻 hands)
 - whisk well (electric works best!)
⠀
💡 Add what ever water proof figurines you have! How about 🚗 car wash or dinosaurs rescue from mud, or unicorns 🦄 in 🌈 foam or giving dolls a bath 🛁 !
⠀
Play foam is amazing to touch! It feels fluffy, soft and smells amazing! Let me know if you tried it!
•••••••
SKILLs:
-🖐🏻 hand 👁 eye coordination
-fine motor control (using tongs)
- also gross motor control when children learn to coordinate larger group muscles
- tactile stimulation
————
AGE 12M+ ⚠️Always supervise your child! Play foam is NOT edible🙊
⠀
❓food coloring will NOT a permanently stain hands or clothes as LONG AS YOU DON’T USE TOO MUCH
❓have a hose or a portable sink or another rinse 🚿 option nearby
‼️the MESS is SO worth the FUN🤩
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕

node.text:
🍉SEED COUNTING
 @MontessoriFromTheHeart ♡
——————
NEW 🍉WATERMELON Activity Pack! Members 📥download from MAIN PORTAL‼️Not a member? Join NOW 🥰
⠀

⠀
If I were to prioritize learning, I would say workbooks are at the bottom of the totem pole. And hands-on MAKING and MANIPULATING are on 🔝🙌🏻! Nothing beats it!
⠀
YOU’LL NEED:
- ♻️ 📦cardboard
- 🍉printables 🖨(Members FREE 📥)
- play dough
- black beans
⠀
AGE: 2 yo+ ⚠️Always supervise your child!
———
💡 Rote Counting vs. Rational Counting:
The difference between rote and rational counting is that the first is a process of sequentially memorizing number names and the second is the process of understanding the value of numbers. If a child is only able to recite numbers in order, just like a heart-learned-poem, it by no means indicates the actual mathematical understanding of numbers. It is thus important, that once a child is able to count to 5 or 10, to shift focus from making that number bigger to making sure that a child can reliably count a small number of manipulatives and assign that quantitative sum to a numeral. Trust me, 1:1 correspondence is a much better indication of your child’s mathematical mastery than a long list of memorized numbers. And the best part, you can introduce 1:1 correspondence starting at an early age by modeling through real-life manipulative and hands-on DIYs. Invite your child to TOUCH each object and provide various hands-on invitations to count, by offering play dough, buttons, 🍉beans, blocks, Lego pieces, food items, etc. Make sure that experiences is fun and engaging in order to sustain curiosity and develop the love for numbers and math.
⠀
⠀
𝒳𝒪, 𝒜𝓃𝓎𝒶𝑴𝒐𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒓𝒊𝑭𝒓𝒐𝒎𝑻𝒉𝒆𝑯𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕
_____________

node.text:
COUNT 🌼DAISY SEEDS
⠀
⠀
________
🚨Check out FLOWER 🌺 BOTANY STUDY under MADE-EASY MEMBER PORTAL!
⠀
Here is a super FUN counting DIY with a memory twist!
⠀
YOU’ll NEED:
- ♻️recycled 📦cardboard (I am using a frozen pizza 🍕 insert)
- tape
- for petals, I used pasta but you can use buttons, pom poms or any other loose items
- dry erase marker
- play dough
⠀
⠀
HOW:
- apply tape to your entire cardboard
- with a dry erase marker write numbers 1-5 (you can modify this to write teen numbers instead)
- have a child erase a number, place yellow play dough disk in the middle and poke the exact quantity of beans as the number erased
⠀
⠀
🧠 MEMORY TRICK: a child has to REMEMBER what number s/he erased to place the exact quantity of beans.
⠀
——
AGE 2.5 Y + ⚠️Always supervise your child!
••••••••••••
💡 THE 🌱BOTANY unit study reveals the importance of of plants to human and animal life. Children are encouraged to look at the many ways 🌱plants provide for our fundamental needs. Botany studies continue with details about the basic needs of plants, the parts, functions, flowers, seeds and so forth.
⠀
🌼Although the center of the flower is called a pistil, the FLAT CENTER of daisy head is made up of many tiny flowers known as disc flowers or florets, which radiate symmetrically from the center of the disc. Within each disc flower is a central pistil topped by a stigma, which is a female reproductive organ that receives the male pollen.
⠀
